metadata.title: Target Encoding and Bayesian Target Encoding | by Michael Larionov, PhD | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Target Encoding and Bayesian Target Encoding
metadata.description: The problem of encoding categorical variables is a very important step in feature engineering. Unfortunately, there is no solution that is working for all cases. Multiple techniques were invented…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: “How to Win a Data Science Competition: Learn from Top Kagglers”

all_paragraphs: The problem of encoding categorical variables is a very important step in feature engineering. Unfortunately, there is no solution that is working for all cases. Multiple techniques were invented, and I cover some of them here, here and here.
In this post I will discuss Target Encoding (a.k.a. Mean Encoding) and its improved version Bayesian Target Encoding, as well as its latest improvement in Sampling Bayesian Encoder.

Given infinite amount of clean data, you will not need to encode categories. You can just train a model for each category. For example, for the Titanic problem you would train separate models for men and women. If you have several categorical variables, you would have to train a new model for every combination of them.
There are obvious problems with this approach:

Generally, this approach often leads to overfitting and is not used for high cardinality categorical variables. However, as demonstrated in [1], it is possible to develop regularization techniques and achieve good generalization for this approach. There this technique was used for modeling DNA sequences.

Generally, encoding of categorical variables is a procedure of replacing categorical variable with one or more numeric variables, so that the resulting data set may be used in the statistical and machine learning algorithms that expect numeric variables. Many encoding techniques, for example, one-hot encoding and ordinal encoding,were developed in early 20th century and they did not lose their importance. Check out a great user guide from scikit-learn. These two techniques become less helpful for high cardinality categorical variables. Ordinal encoding is not able to extract useful information from the categorical variable. One-hot encoding generates too many features for high cardinality categorical variables and also tends to produce poor results. We will consider two types of encoding below that are really effective for high cardinality categorical variables.

This type of encoding is known as Target Encoding or Mean Encoding. Check out a great explanation of this type of encoding in the Coursera course “How to Win a Data Science Competition: Learn from Top Kagglers”
A theoretical basis for this approach was given in the classic paper [2]. The idea is very simple: Let’s use target statistics for encoding the categorical value. As it is described in the paper:

In reality this means that we compute mean for the target variable for each category and encode that category with the target mean. This technique works for both binary classification and regression. For multiclass classification a similar techniques is applied, where we encode the categorical variable with m-1 new variables, where m is the number of classes.

It is worth noting, that even though the author claims to use target statistics for encoding the categorical variable, in reality only mean is used. While it is a sufficient statistic for the binary classification case, for regression it is not, because it ignores intra-category variation of the target variable. This is addressed in Bayesian Target Encoding.

Target (Mean) encoding has a tendency to overfit due to the target leakage. There are various techniques to address this problem. For example, in leave-one-out encoder the current target value is subtracted from the target statistic. This reduces the target leakage. Another technique is to add a Gaussian noise to the encoded value. The intensity of the noise is a hyperparameter of the model.

Another problem is that some of the categories have few training examples, and the mean target value for these categories may assume extreme values, so encoding these values with mean may reduce the model performance. To deal with this issue the target mean for the category is often mixed with the marginal mean of the target variable [2]:
The weights λ are close to one for the categories with many training examples and close to zero for rare categories. For example, it can be parametrized as:

The coefficients λ can be interpreted in terms of Empirical Bayes model. In this case we first we fit the marginal distribution p(y), that is we find the posterior distribution based on the entire data set. Then we can use this posterior distribution as a prior distribution for the model p(y|c), that is the distribution of the target variable given the value of the categorical variable.

These and other variants of Target (Mean) Encoding are implemented in the python package Category Encoders [3]. Different variants of Target Encoding seems to extract slightly different information from the categorical variables, so multiple techniques are often used in various stacking schemes during data science competitions.

The main motivation of Bayesian Target Encoding is to use iner-category variance in addition to the target mean in encoding categorical variables. It was proposed (seemingly independently) in [4,5]. The main insight is that we should compute mean, variance and higher moments of the posterior distribution.

In Bayesian learning the parameters of the distribution are themselves considered random variables. The distribution of parameters before seeing any data is called prior distribution. This distribution is updated based on the new data to become a posterior distribution. The prediction on the unseen data can be derived by marginalizing over the parameter space. To avoid intractable integrals, Bayesian practitioners often use Conjugate Priors. The beauty of them is that they have very simple update rules, that makes it possible to quickly compute posterior distribution based on the training examples. Please see below an excerpt from [5] for more explanations.

For example, consider binary classification problem. Then the binary variable can be described using Bernoulli distribution with only one parameter p, which is a probability that it belongs to the first class. The probability of the second class is q = 1-p. In Bayesian statistics the parameter p is itself a random variable and the conjugate prior is Beta distribution:
The update rules for the parameters of the posterior distribution is very simple:
and the interpretation of the parameters of the posterior distribution is α-1 successes and β-1 failures.
The idea in [4,5] is to count the number of successes and failures for every category and then generate features based on the moments of the posterior distribution: the mean:

The same technique can be used also for regression and multi-class classification models. In [5] this approach is named Conjugate Bayesian model (CBM). For Multi-class models the conjugate prior is Dirichlet distribution, for regression problems it is Normal-Inverse Gamma distribution.

CBM reduces to Target (Mean) Encoding if we only use the first moment of the posterior distribution: its mean. By adding higher moments we can add details of the intra-category distribution of the target variable, which can improve the model performance, provided the same distribution is true for the unseen data. This is a weakness of this approach, because the model may overfit on the higher moments and not generalize on the unseen data. In this case regular target encoding produce better results than CBM.

In [5] the prior distribution is derived by fitting the Bayesian model on the entire set of training data. This is important in order to address a problem of rare categories. In reality you want to control how much the marginal distribution of the target variable influences your posterior distribution, so the prior distribution often has to be scaled down to achieve better model performance.
A good implementation of Bayesian Target Encoding is given in [4]:

It covers only binary classification case. During fit() we compute the number of successes and failures. During transform() phase we generate features with mean and other statistical properties of the conditional distribution, as shown in this excerpt:
A general CBM algorithm is available at a different github encoding:

I wish this category encoding technique were merged into Category Encoders package[3] or another widely used feature engineering library. Also I would like to see more theoretical discussion that would put the Bayesian Target Encoding techniques in a broader context of statistical learning.

A recently published preprint [6] suggests an improvement to the Bayesian Target encoding technique. Instead of using the moments of the posterior distribution as the new features, it suggests to sample the posterior distribution instead, and use the sampled values as the new features. The idea is based on the observation that target encoding in general, and the Bayesian target encoding in particular, can be represented as a hierarchical model that uses weak learners to discover new features. The weak learners are trying to learn the representation of the target variables based on a limited subset of data, in our case — just one variable. Then the predictions produced by weak learners can be used as an input to train a more robust model. This technique is used in ensemble models, such as Random Forest and Gradient Boosted Trees. From the Bayesian perspective, training the model using weak learners can be represented like this:

Let me work you through this equation. In our data set we have M categorical variables, and this means that we train M weak learners for each unique value v of the categorical variable m. Rather than taking the mean we learn a posterior distribution p_mv of the parameters θ given the target value. In general, θ is a vector. Similar to the Bayesian target encoder, we can take several first moments, or in general apply any function f() to the parameters of the posterior distribution. Note that we have not taken the expectation of the parameters yet! We train a model y_θ using the output of these functions as an input (and also the numerical variables ξ that do not require encoding) and only then take the expectation over the posterior distribution. This is the main contribution of the Sampling Bayesian Encoder compared to Bayesian Target Encoder, where the expectation is taken too early — before applying function f(). This helps reduce target leakage and avoid overfitting.

To compute the expectation we can generate a sample from the posterior distribution. Since we used conjugate priors, this is easy. Once we generate a sample we can estimate the expectation in the equation above like this:

K is the sample size, or the number of the parameter sets we generate from the posterior distribution. This approach is similar to multiple imputation approach in statistics. It is also more computationally demanding, especially with the larger K. The code for this paper with all experiments comparing with other methodologies cam be found at this github repo.

Bayesian Target Encoding technique is an improvement over the standard Target Encoding, because it is trying to extract information from intra-category distribution of the target variable, while Target Encoding ignores it. The method has proven very helpful in Kaggle competitions, as well as building a model at WeWork that works on the data with high cardinality categorical variables[5]. Sampling Bayesian Encoder[6] provides a fresh look at the Bayesian Target encoding and opens for more opportunities of research and engineering in the area of encoding of categorical features.
[5] Slakey, Austin & Salas, Daniel & Schamroth, Yoni. (2019). Encoding Categorical Variables with Conjugate Bayesian Models for WeWork Lead Scoring Engine.
